newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: UK, France lose battle on EU fishing cuts.
newsitem.headline: UK, France lose battle on EU fishing cuts.

text.p: European Union fisheries ministers on Tuesday agreed by majority vote to cut fishing by up to 30 percent over five years in a bid to save endangered stocks, officials said.
Britain, which had insisted that the problem of Spanish and Dutch "quota-hoppers" be tackled first, voted against -- as did France, which had called for a 15 percent reduction over three years.

"We are not prepared to continue to see a situation where over a quarter of the British fishing fleet is foreign-owned and foreign-controlled," British Fisheries Minister Tony Baldry told reporters after the vote.
Fisheries is one of the few areas where the EU sets national quotas, he noted, stressing: "UK fish must be for UK fishermen."
He added:"The UK can well meet that (30 percent) target by eliminating quota-hoppers from our register, and that we are determined to do."
Quota-hopping is the practice whereby foreign trawlermen have legally set up flag-of-convenience operations in England to buy licences that give them access to British fishing quotas.

Prime Minister John Major, seeking fishermen's votes in his campaign for the May 1 election, said on Monday he would veto the EU's key inter-governmental conference (IGC) in Amsterdam in June unless the bloc reformed its fishing policies. Major's Conservatives are trailing in the opinion polls.

EU officials said Tuesday's deal, which was reached after Swedish concern over a Baltic cod fishing cutback was resolved, would free up hundreds of millions of dollars of aid to restructure Europe's fishing industry.
The cuts of up to 30 percent cover a five-year period to the end of 2001.

The EU's executive Commission originally proposed a 40 percent reduction over six years but this was fiercely rejected by EU member states, fearful of the political backlash if poor fishing communities were thrown out of work.
EU governments won greater flexibility in choosing whether to cut fish catches by laying up vessels, or by reducing fishing time at sea -- or a combination of both.
Stocks which are overfished, rather than endangered, are subject to a 20 percent reduction by the end of 2001.

Small vessels of less than 12 metres (39 feet) in length, instead of 10 metres (33 feet) in a Dutch EU presidency compromise plan, will be exempted from the cutbacks after pressure from Sweden and other fishing countries.
